016package de.cuioss.test.jsf.junit5;
017
018import static java.lang.annotation.ElementType.TYPE;
019import static java.lang.annotation.RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME;
020
021import java.lang.annotation.Documented;
022import java.lang.annotation.Repeatable;
023import java.lang.annotation.Retention;
024import java.lang.annotation.Target;
025
026import javax.faces.context.FacesContext;
027
028import org.junit.jupiter.api.extension.ExtendWith;
029
030import de.cuioss.test.jsf.config.ApplicationConfigurator;
031import de.cuioss.test.jsf.config.BeanConfigurator;
032import de.cuioss.test.jsf.config.ComponentConfigurator;
033import de.cuioss.test.jsf.config.JsfTestConfiguration;
034import de.cuioss.test.jsf.config.RequestConfigurator;
035import de.cuioss.test.jsf.util.JsfEnvironmentHolder;
036import de.cuioss.test.valueobjects.util.IdentityResourceBundle;
037
038/**
039 * Using this annotations at type-level of a junit 5 test enable the
040 * myfaces-test-based test-framework for unit-tests. The configuration is
041 * implemented using some kind of decorator pattern (roughly). The actual
042 * configuration relies on two sources:
043 * <ul>
044 * <li>It scans for the annotations of type {@link JsfTestConfiguration}
045 * instantiates the corresponding classes and configures the environment
046 * accordingly</li>
047 * <li>It checks whether the actual test-class implements one of
048 * {@link ApplicationConfigurator}, {@link BeanConfigurator},
049 * {@link RequestConfigurator} or {@link ComponentConfigurator} and calls the
050 * corresponding methods accordingly, <em>after</em> the configurator derived by
051 * the annotations</li>
052 * </ul>
053 * <h3>Using</h3>
054 * <p>
055 * Simple Sample: Use a preconfigured JSF-context for the test providing
056 * BasicApplicationConfiguration
057 * </p>
058 *
059 * <pre>
060 * <code>
061     &#64;EnableJsfEnvironment
062     &#64;JsfTestConfiguration(BasicApplicationConfiguration.class)
063     class JSFEnableTest {
064</code>
065 * </pre>
066 *
067 * <p>
068 * Complex Sample: Use a preconfigured JSF-context with access to the context
069 * information like {@link FacesContext}, {@link ComponentConfigurator}, ... as
070 * defined within {@link JsfEnvironmentHolder} With this setup you can
071 * programmatically access the element
072 * </p>
073 *
074 * <pre>
075 * <code>
076     &#64;EnableJsfEnvironment
077     &#64;JsfTestConfiguration(BasicApplicationConfiguration.class)
078     class JsfSetupExtensionTest implements JsfEnvironmentConsumer {
079
080        &#64;Setter
081        &#64;Getter
082        private JsfEnvironmentHolder environmentHolder;</code>
083 * </pre>
084 *
085 * <p>
086 * In addition there is a new way of dealing with localized messages for
087 * unit-tests. In essence there is the {@link IdentityResourceBundle}
088 * configured: This is helpful for tests where you want to ensure that a certain
089 * message key is used to create a message but do not want to test the actual
090 * ResourceBundle mechanism itself. It will always return the given key itself.
091 * As default this mechanism is active, you can change this by setting
092 * {@link #useIdentityResourceBundle()}. If it is active it is used as well for
093 * resolving the MessageBundle. In case of many annotations of
094 * {@link EnableJsfEnvironment} are in the type hierarchy, the one on the most
095 * concrete Type will be chosen, usually on the actual unit-test.
096 * </p>
097 *
098 * @author Oliver Wolff
099 *
100 */
101@Documented
102@Retention(RUNTIME)
103@Target(TYPE)
104@ExtendWith(JsfSetupExtension.class)
105@Repeatable(EnableJsfEnvironments.class)
106public @interface EnableJsfEnvironment {
107
108    /**
109     * @return boolean
110     */
111    boolean useIdentityResourceBundle() default true;
112
113}
